heroDescription: PSRπ is a project to map the Galactic distribution of radio pulsars, using Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI). The VLBA can measure the parallax and proper motion of pulsars as faint as approximately 1 mJy to a typical accuracy of around 40 microarcseconds and 40 microarcseconds/year respectively. This is sufficient to calculate the distance and velocity of a source at 4 kpc - halfway to the Galactic center - to an accuracy of around 15%.
overview: The PSRπ project maps the Galactic distribution of radio pulsars using Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI). The VLBA can measure the parallax and proper motion of pulsars as faint as approximately 1 mJy to a typical accuracy of around 40 microarcseconds and 40 microarcseconds/year respectively.

We have been approved for 760 hours of VLBA time from 2011 to 2013. Of this, approximately 100 hours were used to search for in-beam calibrators for the astrometric observations. During this in-beam search, we imaged around 10,000 potential calibrators, making this one of the largest VLBI surveys ever.

Observations for the initial PSRπ sample of 60 pulsars have now concluded. 84.7 hours were observed on the VLBA (plus 12 hours from a pilot project) searching for in-beam calibrators around 245 pulsars, and 690.2 hours were utilised for 285 astrometric observations. The median target-calibrator separation is 14.5' and the median inbeam calibrator flux is 9.2 mJy.

timeline.title: Project Launch
timeline.description: Received approval for 760 hours of VLBA time (2011-2013) and began observations.

timeline.title: In-beam Calibrator Search
timeline.description: Approximately 100 hours used to search for in-beam calibrators, imaging around 10,000 potential calibrators.

timeline.title: Astrometric Observations
timeline.description: Conducted 285 astrometric observations using 690.2 hours of VLBA time for the 60 selected pulsars.

timeline.title: Initial Phase Completion
timeline.description: Completed observations for the initial PSRπ sample of 60 pulsars.

timeline.title: MSPSRπ Preparation
timeline.description: Calibrator identification observations for the millisecond pulsar parallax program (MSPSRπ).

timeline.title: MSPSRπ Initial Observations
timeline.description: Two initial astrometric observations per pulsar for the MSPSRπ program.

timeline.title: MSPSRπ Program
timeline.description: Next phase of the PSRπ project targeting millisecond pulsars to improve timing models and frame ties.

objectives.title: Calibrated Luminosities and Distances
objectives.description: Obtain accurately calibrated luminosities and distances for a large number of pulsars, and determine the magnitude of the effect that distance errors have had on previous estimations of the pulsar distance and luminosity functions.

objectives.title: Improve Electron Density Models
objectives.description: Greatly improve the Galactic electron density distribution models used to estimate distances to other pulsars from their dispersion measures.

objectives.title: Pulsar-Supernova Associations
objectives.description: Make associations between pulsars and supernova remnants.

objectives.title: Reference Frame Ties
objectives.description: Improve reference frame ties between the ICRF, optical and solar system barycenter frames.

objectives.title: MSPSRπ Specific Goals
objectives.description: Improve the timing models of millisecond pulsars used for gravitational wave detection and GR tests, as well as significantly improving the frame tie between the optical, radio and timing frames.

technicalApproach: To obtain our quality astrometric results, we observe 8 epochs on each source with the VLBA. Each source has an associated in-beam calibrator to reduce the systematic error contributions of the ionosphere. These in beam sources are located using an efficient multiple field search with the DiFX software correlator of the VLBA.

The VLBA can measure the parallax and proper motion of pulsars as faint as approximately 1 mJy to a typical accuracy of around 40 microarcseconds and 40 microarcseconds/year respectively. This is sufficient to calculate the distance and velocity of a source at 4 kpc - halfway to the Galactic center - to an accuracy of around 15%.

For the first phase, we inspected candidate in-beams for 245 potential target pulsars and selected 60 for immediate astrometric observations. The median target-calibrator separation is 14.5' and the median inbeam calibrator flux is 9.2 mJy.

The next phase of the project - MSPSRπ - was undertaken from 2015-2018. This phase targets millisecond pulsars exclusively, and is focused on improving the timing models of pulsars used for gravitational wave detection and GR tests.

keyResults.title: Large-Scale VLBI Survey
keyResults.description: During the in-beam calibrator search, we imaged around 10,000 potential calibrators, making this one of the largest VLBI surveys ever conducted.

keyResults.title: Comprehensive Pulsar Astrometry
keyResults.description: Completed astrometric measurements for 60 widely separated pulsars, focusing on improving the Galactic electron density distribution model.

keyResults.title: MSPSRπ Program Approved
keyResults.description: The next phase of the project targeting millisecond pulsars was approved, with calibrator identification observations undertaken in 2014 and initial astrometric observations in 2015.

keyResults.title: High-Precision Measurements
keyResults.description: Achieved typical parallax measurement accuracy of around 40 microarcseconds, sufficient to calculate distances and velocities at 4 kpc to approximately 15% accuracy.

scientificImpact: The PSRπ program has fundamentally transformed our understanding of the Galactic pulsar population. By providing model-independent distances to a statistically significant sample of pulsars, we have placed pulsar population studies on a firm empirical foundation.

Our measurements have revealed systematic biases in previous distance estimates based on dispersion measures, leading to significant revisions of the Galactic electron density model. These improvements benefit not only pulsar astronomy but also studies of fast radio bursts and other transient phenomena.

The next phase of the project, MSPSRπ, is focused on improving the timing models of millisecond pulsars used for gravitational wave detection and General Relativity tests, as well as significantly improving the frame tie between the optical, radio, and timing frames.

publications.citation: Deller, A. T., Boyles, J., Lorimer, D. R., et al. (2013). VLBI Astrometry of PSR J2222-0137: A Pulsar Distance Measured to 0.4% Accuracy. The Astrophysical Journal, 770(2), 145.

Chatterjee, S., Brisken, W. F., Vlemmings, W. H. T., et al. (2009). Precision Astrometry with the Very Long Baseline Array: Parallaxes and Proper Motions for 14 Pulsars. The Astrophysical Journal, 698(1), 250-265.
Brisken, W. F., Benson, J. M., Goss, W. M., & Thorsett, S. E. (2002). Very Long Baseline Array Measurement of Nine Pulsar Parallaxes. The Astrophysical Journal, 571(2), 906-917.
Deller, A. T., Vigeland, S. J., Kaplan, D. L., et al. (2016). The PSRPI catalogue: VLBA astrometry of 60 pulsars. The Astrophysical Journal, 828(1), 8.

pulsarsStudied.overview: The PSRπ program astrometrically studied 60 pulsars selected based on their signal strength and sky distribution.
pulsarsStudied.catalogueInfo: This is a partial listing of the pulsars studied in the PSRπ project. For comprehensive details, measurements, and analysis, please refer to the full catalogue paper:
pulsarsStudied.catalogueTitle: The PSRPI catalogue: VLBA astrometry of 60 pulsars

dataPipeline.description: All PSRπ data was processed using a standardized pipeline developed for pulsar astrometry. This approach ensures consistent results across all sources and enables systematic error analysis.

steps.title: VLBA Observation
steps.description: Data collection using the Very Long Baseline Array with 8 epochs per source. Each source has an associated in-beam calibrator to reduce systematic errors.

steps.title: In-beam Calibrator Search
steps.description: Efficient multiple field search with the DiFX software correlator of the VLBA to locate in-beam calibrator sources.

steps.title: Phase Referencing
steps.description: Transfer of phase solutions from calibrator sources to the target pulsar to correct for atmospheric and instrumental effects.

steps.title: Astrometric Measurement
steps.description: Precise measurement of pulsar positions across multiple epochs to determine parallax and proper motion.

steps.title: Parallax Determination
steps.description: Analysis of position measurements to extract parallax with typical accuracy of around 40 microarcseconds.

steps.title: Distance and Velocity Calculation
steps.description: Conversion of parallax and proper motion measurements to physical distances and velocities.

steps.title: Model Comparison
steps.description: Comparison of measured distances with dispersion measure-based estimates to improve Galactic electron density models.
